You either jeopardise that service, or you have to run it within the current headcount. I agree that it is important to ensure that the staff who have the skills for the current system are retained for the future. There have been discussions about the importance of that between Siôn and Jim and the PCS and within the LSC.

If I may say so Siôn, we are concerned about the locations of the SFA. We have been told that there will be between 18 and 24 locations. I do not know if the Committee is aware that the LSC has 47 locations, which allows for partnership working and relationship management with local authorities. Those important relationships could easily be lost in the new structures. Given the economic climate, it is important for the Ministers and the Committee to consider whether the locations of the SFA should be increased, especially when there is a possibility of offices sitting vacant with no staff. We could have local, flexible and responsive staff in those locations.
I wanted to ask Julian something else, but does he want to say something briefly on that issue?

Julian Gravatt: I have to agree that the SFA will do a different job from the LSC and that it needs to be appropriately staffed. Our concern is that there seem to be a lot of staff, especially when compared to the equivalent agencies in Scotland and for higher education. We accept that those have a narrower range of duties. Colleges will have to make redundancies this year because of changes in demand for adult learning and the changes in Government funding. There is a difficult climate, but this seems to us to be a missed opportunity in the changes.

The previous group of witnesses said that we should not do this now, that the current staff will not be able to cope in the economic climate and that the strains and stresses are too much. You are effectively saying the opposite, which is that the problem is that we are leaving too many staff and not making the organisation slim enough. Do you think that the truth might lie somewhere in the middle, where we have located it?

Julian Gravatt: This is a complicated change. It is the biggest change in the funding and regulation of colleges for nine years and there must be enough time to ensure that it is done properly and that people are placed correctly. We think that it is possible to put a change through in 2010. We are nervous about the change across to local government, but I am confident that the colleges will make it work.

There has been a ballyhoo about how complicated it is going to be and how colleges will be unable to cope with that. However, the new Skills Funding Agency will have a single account management structure and a single funding conversation for colleges on the adult side. Do your members not tell you that that is positive compared with the multiple conversations that they currently have with the LSC and other funding bodies, and that they look forward to it?
Julian Gravatt: The complication comes from the split at 19.
But on the adult side?

Julian Gravatt: The main issue on the adult side is that the Skills Funding Agency works in a joined-up way with the YPLA and local authorities, so we are particularly keen that clause 119, which allows it to share data, will actually require it to work in concert as well.
But is a single account structure for colleges a positive thing?
Julian Gravatt: Yes it is, with the proviso that it is only for the adult area and that colleges have more of their work in the 16-to-19 area for both education and apprenticeships.
May I ask Graham about the single account point? We are trying to make it easier.

Graham Moore: There are two things to remember. A single account is clearly a good idea; I do not think that anybody would dispute that. It is what the account and its complexity are all about. You have to remember that the SFA does not actually deliver anything. The delivery has to be done through the provider network with employers and so on, which is where you want to put most resources to ensure that you can do the maximum to help the nation.

If you look at the complexity behind that single voice from the SFA, you will see that it is about its funding methodology and its rules and regulations on what you can and cannot do. You are not actually saying, “We want to make a difference. These are the issues in your community, and the employers say this and the local authorities say that.” You try to come to an agreement on how to address the Government’s priorities in your local area, and I stress that that is where the difference needs to be made, and not on a national level. The strategy is quite clear and we all know what needs to be done. You need a relatively simple, unbureaucratic system, and I am not certain that with 1,800 people you will actually get that.
Mr. Tuckett wants to join in.

Alan Tuckett: There will inevitably be quite a lot of transitional traction for people who do not chronologically grow at the rate that our legislative arrangements plan for them: adults with learning difficulties at 26 whose needs are no different from those of 24-year-olds, for example, or young offenders aged 18 to 24, rather than 16 to 18. The issues relating to negotiation between young people’s funding agencies, the SFA and local authorities to ensure that individuals do not get lost along the way seem to be as significant as the coherence issue for institutions, since the devil is always in the detail for post-compulsory participation, Siôn.

The previous group that gave evidence was asked about the business-friendly side of SFA, which I am sure is right. But the risk is that the wider economic and social well-being and responsibility, which are very clearly located in young people’s work, will be harder to secure as a coherent dialogue between the different funding agencies to enable institutions to operate in a holistic way.

The London Apprenticeship Company was recently established, and the Federation of Small Businesses states that the company has been particularly useful in helping small and medium-sized enterprises in London to find apprenticeship places and match them up with small employers. The AOC’s evidence seems to encourage group training associations, which are largely the same. Do you think that the Bill goes far enough in facilitating group training arrangements?

Julian Gravatt: It is not necessary to legislate on every area of activity that you want to achieve. Sometimes, the main issue is ensuring that legislation does not have unintended consequences and does not make it more difficult to achieve certain things. I do not know the details of the London apprenticeship arrangements, but I certainly know that colleges are working across the country on arrangements with small employers to develop apprenticeships. Our concern is about the restriction that the apprentice must be employed at all stages. In some cases and in group arrangements with small employers, it might cover the risks if, for example, the colleges or a third party employed apprentices and they are placed in different places. So our concern is to ensure that there are not unintended consequences from how the Bill is phrased.

To be clear about that, the Association of Colleges would welcome the opportunity—perhaps the 157 Group might want to comment on this too—for colleges to be the formal employer of an apprentice in a programme-led apprenticeship programme.

Julian Gravatt: Colleges already are the formal employer of a couple of thousand apprentices and we have plans to encourage that further, for example, through our contractors, such as those constructing college buildings, so that they can employ apprentices. Our concern is to ensure that the way that the Bill is phrased and then implemented does not create an unintended obstacle.

In response to the first question, we heard from the Local Government Association that there are anxieties about working across local authority borders. Clearly, there are an awful lot of new responsibilities for local authorities in the Bill. So my first question is, broadly, how do you think that some of the transition preparation work is going, from a local government perspective?

My second question is specifically related to clauses 47 to 50, which are about young offenders. I know that the numbers are relatively small; we are talking about 3,000 young people here who would become the responsibility of the local authority. How confident are you that the transition and the care that those young people receive will be handled smoothly and well? I ask that because the last thing we want is those young people, who in some cases are already struggling with education provision, again falling between two stools of local authorities arguing about funding or anything else.

Graham Moore: There is a lot of good will at local authority level, and I have been party to some negotiations at local level, although I am sure that negotiations are different across the country. So officers clearly want to work together to try to make this system work. The issue is about the politicians, their role and their loyalty, if you like, to their community, which makes it a little difficult for officers to give up some authority to neighbouring local authorities when sometimes local authorities have fought very hard to gain their independence and control. That is an area of concern.

We were also particularly concerned with the relatively small number of young offenders that you are talking about. Again, that is an added complexity for local authorities, which, it seems to me, do not need those added complexities at the moment. If we can see that more as part of a national scheme that we are supporting, local authorities’ responsibility comes when the young offenders have to be placed back in the community and in the normal education system. That is where I would like to see the local authorities focus their attention. They should make certain that there are proper transitional arrangements, so that when somebody comes out of an institution, they are properly looked after and there is proper funding attached to them, so that they can have the right sort of education to come back into the community, and get the skills that will make them a full part of the community rather than an outcast.

I want to ask Alan Tuckett a question. How far do you think the Bill will go in reversing the serious decline in the number of adult and community learning places? There has been a decline of 1.4 million in the last few years, according to the National Institute of Careers Education and Counselling.

Alan Tuckett: I do not think that the Bill, in its current form, addresses the issues that the Government will address through the informal adult learning White Paper, which is around the corner. So it is the articulation of that policy, which is soon to be announced, that will help us to be in a position to make a judgment about the net effect overall.

However, we have concerns about the current framing of the legislative weight attached post-19 to educational opportunities, that is the definitions in the Bill. You asked a question earlier about the extent to which, in our proper concern to get a skilled and educated work force, routes other than formal qualifications help towards that end. We have real concerns that a demand-led system, driven in the way that the White Paper illustrated and the Bill backs up, will not allow adequately for individuals to be trusted to find their own routes towards learning.

Although Tom Wilson said very firmly that we do not have to see education and training as a zero-sum game, in practice what happens is a transfer of resources from relatively intensive investment in a smaller number of people away from extensive engagement with very large numbers of people and, frankly, we need both in a learning society. We need to help people to put their toe in the water, and I do not see that encouragement here. The arrangements for stimulating and encouraging people are not permissive enough for people who did not enjoy education and training the first time around. We need to encourage them to be effective learners if they are to re-engage with—and sustain realistic sustainable work in—the labour market.

So a more responsive system might involve a slimmer system altogether: deregulated colleges, a bottom-up approach, a highly localised system that placed more emphasis on a diversity of individual learning requirements—credited, non-accredited, different routes back into learning.

Alan Tuckett: I do not know if it is slimmer, but it is certainly more locally determined. The dilemma is that there are things that you need to plan nationally—clear, national strategic interventions around major skills needs—but for most adults re-engaging with learning, decision making is made at an extremely local level and you need to be able to engage there. Providers need to be able to respond to demands in their immediate patch, and what is true in Stoke will not be true in Brighton.

I have one final question. The 157 Group says that it is concerned about the levels of powers coming to the Skills Funding Agency in producing draft specifications for apprenticeship framing standards. Both the Association of Colleges and the 157 Group have argued that there is not enough about capital funding for further education in the Bill.

Graham Moore: It is a big crisis at the moment. In the sector we are looking to some progress from the LSC and the Department, but how many separate capital funding flows should we have for education? How should we be organising them? Are we looking at them in a joined-up way? What do we want the education sector to look like? What do we want our universities, colleges and schools to look like? Could we not have a joined-up, consistent and properly-funded capital policy?

I know that it is not a very good time to say those things, because times are getting hard, but colleges have been put into a situation where most of us who want new buildings have put substantial money into the preliminary process. Some £100 million or so in the sector is at risk. To have one plan, and now another plan coming forward, is causing us some disquiet and may put the viability of institutions at risk—it is significant. Our plea is just that there should be a joined-up process. Is the Bill an opportunity to chart what a capital strategy for education might look like?

Ann Robinson: I want to add that of those colleges, several are sixth-form colleges, so we have the same concerns. Looking to the future, one suggestion that we have put forward is that there should be, at least in the transition period of the new machinery, a common capital fund for all colleges—including sixth-form colleges—to try to avoid any tying up of sixth-form colleges, newly, with Building Schools for the Future where they might be behind, or ahead, of the local authorities that they are joining.

I shall resist the temptation to start a debate about the huge growth in capital funding for FE colleges and put my question in the negative, just to save time. Is there anyone, from the witnesses here, who disagreed with raising the participation age, and who therefore disagrees with the consequent shifting of the break in education from 16 to 19?
Julian Gravatt: We fully supported it.

Alan Tuckett: On the second half of your question, not the first, the shift from 16 to 19 merely displaces the point at which people who are not ready, or who drop out and drop back in again, find the system does not work for them. Our institution’s perspective is that by 25 pretty much everybody is experiencing the common experiences of adult life but, for many people up until that age, and if you include higher education in particular, labour market entry or preparation for adult life is their co-ordinating focus.

I do not disagree with raising the education participation age in the legislation, but I think that the temptation is to collect statistics at 19, which disguises the complexity of later maturing. That is a problem for us in planning for the long run.
That is helpful. The temptation is around 25.

Graham Moore: You are not raising the school leaving age; you are raising the participation age, and I think that the Bill has a significant gap in it. It talks about full-time education and apprenticeships, but it is very vague about other duties employers might have that take on 16 to 18-year-olds and are not offering an apprenticeship. The way the Bill is drafted, they could get away with almost any sort of training and it might qualify.

You also put an onus on the employee to request training, but the duty should be placed on the employer. If you take on somebody under 19, you should not have any choice but to provide a proper quality training programme. It does not have to be an apprenticeship, but the Bill leaves that wide open to abuse.

I will resist giving a lecture on what was in the recently passed Education and Skills Act 2008 and, in view of the time, ask a second slightly negative question. Given the broad, but not complete, support for making the break at 19, do any witnesses think that there is a better way of aggregating local authority commissioning of post-16 learning to create the single conversation, rather than the sub-regional grouping brokered by the YPLA route, which we designed and is reflected in the legislation?

Julian Gravatt: The AOC has been very closely involved in the development of sub-regional groups, which we welcome. It will be important, with the local government role, to recognise the differences between different parts of the country. We have slight reservations about the different 16-to-19 institutions being commissioned at different levels depending on the details—for example, school sixth forms and sixth-form colleges being commissioned by the home local authority, FE colleges by the sub-regional group, and certain, not yet known, national providers being commissioned at national level.

We suggested early on that it might have made more sense for it all to be done by the sub-regional group in places, such as London and Manchester, where there is lots of trouble across boundaries, for example, and for it all to be done by the county in other parts of the country—often the shire counties—where there is not much movement outside. It is not something specifically covered in the Bill and there is always the opportunity to see how it works.
You are arguing not with the basic structure in the Bill, but with some implementation issues.
Julian Gravatt: Yes, and it remains to be seen exactly how it will work. There will also be areas, such as where unitary councils have been created, where working together may cause problems.
Ruth, then David and then Ann, if that is all right, Mr. Chope.

Ruth Serwotka: I do not think that I have an answer for Jim about a better way of doing it, but we have concerns about the proposals. Taking London as an example, you have, I think, 33 authorities that will combine in a single sub-regional group and are then supposed to commission learning across boundaries, but have no statutory implement or authority to do so. They are supposed to be commissioning and planning on quite an informal basis.

Trying to get 33 local authorities to agree on priorities and on the complexity of the cross-boundary travel-to-learn patterns and so on is going to be very challenging indeed. One of our previous proposals, which I doubt everyone on this panel would accept, is that instead of arrangements being made around sub-regional groupings and staff being transferred to local authorities to set up those commissioning relationships, there should be more centralism with regard to the YPLA and Governments should have a closer relationship with the commissioning, especially when, in the current climate, bogus providers, as The Observer recently reported, are setting themselves up and pretending to deliver courses to the unemployed. That could be abused in the current system, so we need to think about the current climate and maybe review some of those structures, because they are very informal.

David Igoe: Julian implied that the arrangements for sixth-form colleges and schools will be different from those for FE colleges because they will be commissioned by the local authority while FE will be commissioned by the sub-regional group. I do not think that that is quite right, because it has been shown that sixth-form colleges, with regard to cross-border recruitment, are at least as complex as FE, so sixth-form colleges will certainly want to be part of the sub-regional conversation and feature in it. Of course, work will need to be done on the detail of exactly how the two will interrelate.

I, too, am a sixth-form college principal, and I find that in conversations on the ground we do not really mind who comes and has the conversation with sixth-form colleges about how much money we will have, so long as the amount is right and fair. We are getting bogged down in that process. Whatever the arrangements, they have to be fair and be seen to be fair, which relates to my first point, and that will depend on the instruments used to judge where funding is placed.

Whether that will be the primary responsibility of the YPLA, or whether local authorities will have to take on board a national scheme of performance management so that they are confident that they are commissioning places in the right way, is where that particular process will stand or fall. How many processes and levels it goes through, whether local, regional or sub-regional, is much less of a concern than how and by what means the pot is divvied up, and we need that to be a transparent process.

Ann Robinson: I agree with David entirely about that but worry about unintended consequences, because although I do not suppose that you could commission without taking the sixth-form college perspective into account—it is a sort of chicken and egg situation—it is possible that some local authorities will limit student choice by seeing sixth-form colleges as very much more local than they currently are in their recruitment. We hope that local authorities will in no way become proprietorial about their sixth-form colleges and try to limit their places to students within their boundaries.
Do you think that the duty to give impartial advice, as set out in the Education and Skills Act 2008, is pertinent to that?

Ann Robinson: I think that it is and that the intention is absolutely right. It is just how it is managed in practice that worries me, because there is almost exactly the same recruitment across borough boundaries for sixth-form colleges as there is for general FE colleges. That is one of their great strengths: they recruit students from areas where sometimes there is no good sixth-form provision and take them into a large community that is, by research and reputation, often mixed to a degree that their local area is not. That provides opportunities for students from deprived areas to get high-quality education outside their own boroughs where necessary, and we would be very unwise to lose that strength when making new arrangements for sixth-form colleges.

Graham Moore: I believe that there is another way. If we genuinely believe in demand-led funding and that funding should follow the learner, which we have talked an awful lot about, a sum of money should be attached to every individual, and having been given good advice and guidance, they should be able to chose which institution best suits their needs, and the funding should follow.

You are committed to funding those individuals anyway, although you do not have to have commissioning in the same way. You focus local authorities on the quality of the providers on their patch and the gaps in provision. You then work by exception, which is a much lighter load for local authorities. They are not interfering all the time; they are simply intervening when they and their community are short-changed. If you embrace demand-led funding, attach money to individuals and let those individuals choose where they go, so that whichever institution they go to, you get the same sum of money. That gets rid of some of the problems about differential funding for different institutions, which cause us a lot of angst, and means that those individuals will have a good choice.

We will all be out there offering our wares, trying to make them as attractive and relevant as possible. It is a less planned approach, but a fairer and more sensible one. It will lead to some decline and some expansion, but that is what the system should do.
Alan Tuckett: The danger is for people who cannot make those choices independently or who drop out of the system. They need somebody’s active intervention to look after their interests and needs.
Graham Moore: I agree there will be such groups.
We have to move on. I have Annette Brooke, then John Hayes, then Stephen Williams.
I want to change track and look at the new duties to co-operate with relevant partners and to promote well-being, which some of you have already touched on.
Some institutions have made the point that the duty to co-operate will affect their independence. I am interested in how positively or negatively you see those new duties.

Julian Gravatt: When the AOC was consulted about the duty to co-operate, as in clause 184, we said that on balance we thought it the right thing to do, but that it should also cover academies, universities and further education. So, we are glad that the Government listened to what we and the LGA said. We have some nervousness about another potential set of meetings for college leaders, but we see that colleges make a vital contribution to the wider agenda of the children’s trusts and that it is better to be within that alongside schools, rather than without it.

Alan Tuckett: We are wholly in favour of it. We think that the reification of the independence of institutions at the expense of people who drop through the hoops in a system where there is not enough resource to go round makes the duty to co-operate really welcome.

Thank you. Another duty you will have relates to when force is used on students. Do you see that as onerous? Do you feel there is sufficient training in the use of force and in the reporting, which will be quite significant?

Ann Robinson: We would welcome it—to be used carefully and with training for people to understand what it means and how to exercise powers. We should take on those responsibilities very seriously as part of the pastoral care of the student body and of individuals.

Is there great likelihood of local authorities becoming proprietorial? Are they more or less likely to do so? Would any of you, if you had started with a blank sheet of paper, have constructed a management and funding regime of the type in the Bill, particularly with local authority involvement?

David Igoe: From a sixth-form college perspective, as I said at the outset, we are relatively relaxed about not going back to where we were—everyone recognises there is no going back—but having stronger involvement with local authorities. It makes sense in terms of planning the local provision, which has to include schools, colleges and, increasingly, FE colleges. It is a lot more complicated than people understood. It was not well understood how many young people were in FE generally.

Birmingham is an interesting example. I was dealing with some figures on it last week and 57 per cent. of 16 to 18-year-olds still in education are in FE colleges. That does not include those in sixth-form colleges because they make up another 15 per cent. Only 23 per cent. of Birmingham’s 16 to 18-year-olds are in schools. Looking at how that cohort of young people is educated demonstrates that this is a complex picture.

There should be a single authority to look at that, otherwise there will be the endless see-saw that we have experienced over the last few years. We need and want to co-operate with all the providers in our patch, but find ourselves in an intensely competitive environment. That is almost impossible to manage and we would like some relief from it.

To go back to whether the local authority will interfere with our independence and our ability to recruit in the way that we want, we do not think that it will, provided that the fundamental principles underlying the Bill are followed. We will see how that works in practice. The principle is that the funding must follow the learner. We must be vigilant so that restrictive practice is not allowed to creep in, either by the removal of transport subsidy or influence on particular schools. It must not interfere with the young person’s ability to make a free and unfettered choice about where they would best be educated. The advice that they get must be genuinely independent. These are all question marks because we are going into a new environment.
Can you keep your remarks brief as I would like to get two more colleagues in?

Julian Gravatt: We would like local authorities to feel proprietorial about their colleges and to see them as important institutions in the area. David mentioned the large number of 16 to 18-year-olds who are in colleges and the work that they do. The important thing is to respect the boundaries between the responsibilities of different organisations. We suggested early on that it might have made sense for the cash not to go through local authorities, but for them to have a role just in the dialogue and the commissioning. Some of the complexity of the Bill comes from the structure of direct funding relationships for local authorities.
This is not about direct funding. The Bill gives them a direct role of the kind you say is not helpful. This is not about being friends with your local authority.
Julian Gravatt: No. When it works well, that is fine. Our concern is about what protections the Bill has for colleges, their learners and their staff when it does not work well.

Alan Tuckett: For adults, we think it a good idea to split the departments as long as there is a single funding agency to ensure that their separate decisions are made coherent in the middle. Once they are separated, it is even more important that someone takes an overarching view of what is going on.

Local government has a wider responsibility for the welfare of communities than merely the delivery of their education and training systems. The catalytic function of adult participation in education and training makes an enormous difference to health policy, community cohesion, crime reduction and so on. It is very difficult to see how you can avoid local government being engaged at the centre of the system. That is a price we have been paying for the last 10 years.

I have a penultimate question and a final question. First, advice and guidance have been mentioned several times. The Bill will place a duty on those providing advice to consider the best interests of the pupil, but not necessarily to put forward all options to them. Are you concerned about whether advisers will be sufficiently independent of the setting in which they give the advice, which is likely to be a school in the early stages, to be truly objective about what path a young person should follow?

Ann Robinson: That is a perennial problem that we have lived with for a long time. We are not entirely confident about that. Earlier today, the advice about apprenticeships was mentioned. We certainly want to ensure that it is strengthened. There is a slight question mark over people who are commissioning and giving advice and who are also providers. They are perhaps a little tied up, a little entwined.
Can we come on to your next question and then I hope we can get the Minister involved?

My final question—Alan might want to comment on the advice to adults—is on the funding and policy direction. Might it be better to have a single adult funding council, bringing together higher education, further education and skills, so that there is policy coherence and funding coherence, and everyone can look to one quango, non-departmental public body or whatever it would be?

Alan Tuckett: The answer to the question you directly asked is yes. In the long run in Britain, the artificial distinctions between further and higher cannot be sustained. I know that there is a political set of challenges in finding a fiscal system that makes that work. You look at Wisconsin and the transitional barriers to taking learning further are much lighter where you have one system.

If I can come back to advice, we would really like to see—we hope we might persuade you to look at this as the Bill goes through—the Adult Advancement and Careers Service being put on to a statutory basis comparable to the young people’s one. We think the move has been really positive, giving for the first time a coherent tension to the issue, but, after 30 years’ experience of almost jumping on the bandwagon of adult advice and then running away from it, the long-term risk is that if you do not put it on a statutory basis, that will happen again.

It would be remiss not to take the last four minutes to ask Ann and David in particular how the sixth-form college sector differs from GFE colleges. Is it right that they should be able to self-determine under the Bill which they want to be? What benefit does a separate distinction offer, if any?

Ann Robinson: Minister, I think I heard you saying at the AOC conference recently that the distinction is in performance management by the local authority. That is the one that we are still seeing as the key.
But how are they different now?

Ann Robinson: Some are not very different. There is more difference in character among sixth-form colleges since incorporation than there is among GFEs. Some sixth-form colleges are more like GFEs than they are like other sixth-form colleges. The success of this legislation will be affected by that.

Where a sixth-form college is like a GFE, and in the context where that is going to be very significant for commissioning, there may be some difficulty with the sub-regional partnerships or sub-regional groupings not taking everybody up together. Where a sixth-form college is very like a sixth form, it will perhaps sit more easily into the new local authority arrangements. It is a difficult one to call.

David Igoe: I want to highlight the muddiness of the waters. We compartmentalise institutions and sectors. That is wrong. Sixth-form colleges have a reasonably single focus on progression issues for young people into higher education and employment in a way that is fairly consistent and much more coherent with what is happening in the schools sector. Also, what distinguishes sixth-form colleges is their consistent high quality. That is what has been a feature of the sector since incorporation. That is what we want to try to retain.
And stronger pastoral care?

David Igoe: Again, there is a lot of mythology about this. Good pastoral care is a feature of sixth-form colleges, but that is not to say that it does not exist in good proportion in lots of FE colleges—certainly in tertiary colleges and in schools. You are forcing us into making invidious comparisons.

Julian Gravatt: Several 16-to-18 schools will have the benefit of getting sixth-form college status. There are great advantages in the incorporated status, which sixth-form colleges and FE colleges have had.
Mr. Moore wants to have the last word.

Graham Moore: Sixth-form colleges are not evenly distributed over the country. In many parts of the country, a GFE college would have a very strong focus on 16-to-18. Tertiary colleges often do that. When you look at it on the ground, the differences between the institutions are very marginal. It is horses for courses wherever you are in the country.

That conveniently brings us to the end of the time allocated for questions. Thank you very much, all of you, for coming along and keeping your answers so brief and relevant. We are most appreciative of that.
Ordered, That further consideration be now adjourned. —(Ms Butler.)

p.span: Adjourned till this day at Four o’clock.
